awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: Jammed granular matter within networks of pins: Structure, elasticity, plasticity and rheology under shear
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract:
Granular Materials are ubiquitous in daily life. By “granular” one means not only hard objects like salt, rice, or sand; but also soft objects like bubbles, and living entities like cells and pedestrians. Dense granular materials can behave dramatically by clogging, avalanching, or suddenly solidifying into a disordered “jammed” structure.  This research project asks the question: How do these phenomena manifest themselves when the grains are in contact with a fixed framework? In this research, the framework is a lattice of diminutive obstacles, or “pins”.  (In two dimensions, one might think of the pins in a Pachinko game.) Pins influence both when a sudden transition occurs in a granular packing, and the structure and dynamics of the jammed solid which forms. Beyond its theoretical interest, this project has applications like utilizing obstacles for the prevention of jamming of particles or people; and making new jammed materials which are more elastic and less bulky. The influence of pins on the material’s structure and dynamics is studied both with experiments as well as computer simulations. The principal investigators are four faculty members, with an experimental and a computational physicist at each one of two institutions which offer only undergraduate degrees in physics.  Their students work directly with faculty to experience computational and/or experimental research in a field that is both theory-rich and highly practical. 

Technical Abstract:
Packings of granular materials, as for example in industrial supply lines or in living organisms, exhibit striking changes in structural or flowing behavior such as abrupt rearrangements, collapses and sudden blockading of channels. Such changes are due to geometrical frustration, as grains experience clogging and jamming transitions. Deformation and flow are largely determined by system-spanning force networks, which broker a compromise between external forces and torques, confinement, and internal granular interactions. While there have been many studies of dense granular matter, there have been few on the rheology of granular systems which include an effect reminiscent of confinement: frozen degrees of freedom in the form of localized pinning sites internal to the system. This project, which addresses critical, open questions on spatial correlations of stress and flow fields, is a systematic study of how the presence of such pins, either in the form of a lattice or a disordered array (hence, quenched order or disorder) influences structure and flow. Activities of the principal investigators include determining the phase diagram for this novel order/disorder transition; calculating elastic moduli, local stress fields and parameters characterizing the force network as influenced by pinning geometry;  use of particle-scale tracking to describe packing structure and kinematics due to microscopic rearrangements under shear; and first steps toward extending these insights to active granular matter.  The work entails both numerical simulation and experiments through a collaboration between four investigators at two primarily undergraduate institutions. Experiments involve planar, simple, and Couette shear using two-dimensional assemblies of photoelastic grains.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

NSF grant DMR-1905474  (PI A. Graves and co-Pi C. Bester, Swarthmore College) has been in collaboration with a sister grant DMR-1905737 (PI K. Vollmayr-Lee, Bucknell University and consultant B. Utter, UC Merced).

This work concerns the "physics of everyday things"; granular and/or soft particles of the type one encounters in the real world: foams, sand, emulsions, or living cells. With increasing density, a disordered soft/granular system - like cancer cells, coffee grounds, or the material that composes body armor - undergoes a transition from liquid-like to solid-like behavior.  In the solid state, the system is said to be "jammed". 

We study a theoretical jamming problem with practical consequences, using computer simulation (Investigators: Vollmayr-Lee and Graves), experiments (Investigators: Bester and Utter), and also machine learning (Investigators: Graves and Morgan). These approaches have a common goal:  to understand the jamming transition and the mechanical properties of the jammed solid when a two-dimensional layer of soft grains is supported by tiny, immobile anchoring points which we term "pins". We have found that pins allow us to alter the jamming threshold, reducing the amount of material needed for jamming; and tailor mechanical properties of the solid like its stiffness and resistance to being plastically deformed.

Fig.1 shows our simulated two dimensional system of a binary mixture of purely repulsive disks with the additional pins on a square lattice, and related experimental setups. Increasing pin density and/or changing the geometry of pin placement will alter the jamming threshold; the generic result is that pins reduce the amount of material needed for jamming to occur.  Fig. 2 illustrates how the structure of contacts between particles takes on the symmetry of the pin lattice.

We simulated shear and compression by moving the top and/or bottom particulate walls, (in yellow in Fig. 1) at a constant rate. Pins strongly influence the sheared rheology (Fig. 3), impeding velocity propagation from the walls to the center. Velocities are well fit by a "back of the envelope" model (fit lines in Fig. 3) with a single, characteristic length scale - approximately the distance from the wall to the nearest pin layer, also half the distance between pins. 

To visualize dynamics at the microscopic level, Fig. 4 shows force networks. Line thickness is proportional to the magnitude of the force between the two particles. Pins that are not structurally necessary (experiencing zero force) are shown in black, the necessary pins are shown in red. The evolving network shows intermittent local clusters of strong forces.

As we learned from the velocity profile, the walls break the symmetry and introduce a dependence of force statistics on the distance to the wall. We find that pins allow for more weak forces and also lead to an increased tail in the probability distribution, consisting of large forces. These effects are systematically greater nearer to the wall. Enhancement of both strong and weak forces agree with our earlier simulations (Zhang et al, 2022) without of shear or symmetry-breaking walls.   Experimental data on planar shear of 2d photoelastic granular system (Fig. 4) show that a small number of pins produces intermittent arching of force chains (between pins or a pin and wall). Larger arrays of pins produce shielding in the nearly static interior region.

We find that the sheared system is both more stiff (higher elasticity) and more plastic ( lower yield stress) when pins are present.  These technologically important effects are shown in Fig. 5.  In Fig. 6 we show a map of locations where particles are likely to shift their positions, and rearrange non-affinely.  One can see the effect of proximity to a pin, as well as proximity to a wall - a direct consequence of the pin lattice concentrating shear near walls.

This grant has led to very strong collaborations between three institutions: Bucknell U. Swarthmore College, and U.C. Merced. Via regular Zoom sessions, we developed computer codes, experimental procedures, and wrestled with the interpretation of results.  Over five years, we have mentored 23 undergraduates.  Students have presented at local and national meetings, and authored literature papers. They been trained to do computer simulations and calculations on laptops, NSF supercomputers, and the Cloud. They’ve done experiments and computer-aided experimental analysis. Our distant teams typically zoomed once a week so students could give updates on their work. We also had "journal club" meetings to dissect articles in the physics literature.  For new students, we organized weekly skill-building sessions in topics like research practices and scientific communication. 

We are proud of the terrific outcomes for graduated students. They've won collegiate prizes and national fellowships which were partly based on their research with us.  Virtually all have gone on to teaching STEM and/or top-level PhD programs in STEM, where they will become fully-fledged scientists in fields like physics, mathematics, and geosciences.

  • A measure of non-affine displacement for a particle, D2min, exceeds a critical values when plastic rearrangement is likely. The probability that a location has particles with D2min greater than the critical value is shown for (a) 0 pins (b) 16 pins.

    Public Domain

    Locations of probable rearrangement
  • As the number density of pins increases, the yield stress (blue) falls, while the initial slope of stress vs. strain curve (orange) rises. Thus the system becomes more plastic, and stiffer.
    DMR-1905474 and 1905737 Research Groups
    Public Domain
    Amy Graves
    Elasticity and Plasticity
  • (a) A simulation of 4096 (red, blue) particles with large and small sizes preventing crystalization. 64 (green) pins are exaggerated for visibility, Rough walls (yellow) can be moved vertically/laterally, to produce compression/shear. (b) Experiment with several hundred soft discs and 4 pins.
    DMR-1905474 and 1905737 Research Groups
    Public Domain
    Amy Graves
    Jammed particles with pins
  • 230 particles exist in a jammed configuration with 64 pins. Red lines are diameters of large and small particles respectively. Color map denotes likelihood of contact between two particles at that location (yellow:likely to purple:unlikely). (a) square pin lattice (b) triangular pin lattice.
    DMR-1905474 and 1905737 Research Groups
    Public Domain

    Heatmap of contacts between particles
  • Particles are sandwiched between walls moving left and right (the x direction). The horizontal velocity profile deviates further from a straight line as pin density, nf, is increased. A back-of-the envelope model featuring a harmonic field of force provides an excellent fit to data.
    DMR-1905474 and 1905737 Research Groups
    Public Domain

    Velocity in direction of shear vs. distance from walls
  • (a),(b) Two snapshots of forces in 255 pin shearing simulation, separated by the time in which walls move 3%. Line thickness denoting force strength. Experiment with a small number of pins shows (c) force chains terminating on pins and (d) strong forces and static clog.
